channel.title: Knowledge@Wharton
channel.description: Knowledge@Wharton is the online business analysis journal of the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania.

item.title: UAE Ambassador Omar Saif Ghobash: ISIS Should Be Fought in the Realm of Ideas
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: UAE Ambassador to Russia Omar Saif Ghobash speaks about ISIS, Ukraine and Western education in the Middle East.

item.title: Hospital Advertising: Good Business, or Time to Pull the Plug?
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: Free-commerce advocates say that hospitals should be able to advertise just like any other business, while others argue that the proliferation of health care advertising raises serious ethical issues that need to be addressed.

item.title: Right-sizing Support Functions Part I
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: Support function inefficiencies are not “laying around on the shop floor” for all to see. So how can you find and purge them?

item.title: When Fewer Choices Are Worth More
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: When it comes to matching platforms like online dating sites, sometimes less choice is better -- and worth paying for.

item.title: Will Microsoft Change the Game with Its Mojang Acquisition?
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: Will Microsoft's $2.5 billion acquisition of video game producer Mojang make the firm more relevant to a younger generation of consumers?

item.title: What Employers Should Learn from Wal-Mart’s Dress Code Controversy
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: Wal-Mart's plan to toughen its employee dress code was a good marketing move that backfired, according to Wharton's Deborah Weinstein.

item.title: Brand Challenge: Is There a ‘Recipe’ for Going Viral?
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: Digitally savvy brands that meet consumers on their own terms can drive greater engagement, write Google’s Kelli Wasuri and Gopi Kallayil in this opinion piece.

item.title: Financial Inclusion in India: Moving Beyond Bank Accounts
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: A program in India to increase financial inclusion made rapid progress in opening bank accounts for underserved populations -- but it has also raised numerous questions about what still needs to be done.

item.title: What Social Networks Can Teach Us about How the Brain Works
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: Penn's Danielle S. Bassett, 32, the youngest of this year's MacArthur fellows, talks about her research in understanding how the human brain functions.

item.title: Is Every Lie ‘a Sin’? Maybe Not
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: When is honesty not the best policy and deception morally correct? More often than you might think, as it turns out.

item.title: Why Child Care Is the Economy’s ‘Invisible’ Driver
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: Child care -- or the lack of affordable care options -- is a multi-layered economic issue that has wide-ranging repercussions for the U.S. and globally. But even as costs continue to go up, few concrete solutions are in sight.

item.title: Capital Flight: Can Tax Inversions Be Prevented?
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: Legislators in Washington are up in arms over a wave of companies pursuing overseas acquisitions so they can escape high U.S. taxes. But can the capital flight be stopped?

item.title: When Taking a Break Could Be a Matter of Life and Death
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: New Wharton research finds that over the course of a work day, employees pay less and less attention to the secondary tasks that, while not as central to their jobs, can create big problems if overlooked.

item.title: The Dark Side of Big Data
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: Big Data is poised to play a powerful role in sustainability. But that power can be abused and it could remain cloistered in the developed world, providing scant benefit to those who most need it.

item.title: Can Big Data Feed the World?
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: How will we feed the one billion people now going hungry, plus nearly two billion more mouths by 2050? Big Data could help increase food supplies while using less water, fertilizer and energy.

item.title: Big Data and Energy: A Clear Synergy
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: Utilities and energy companies are finding big savings in Big Data. The flood of new information arrives just as boosting fuel efficiency becomes a top priority.

item.title: What Big Data Can Mean for Sustainability
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: More data is now generated in a couple of days than the human race produced in the past two millennia. Increasingly, large chunks of it are helping to deflect some of the negative effects of climate change.

item.title: Farewell, Emilio Botin: Banco Santander Prepares for Tomorrow
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: With the death of chairman Emilio Botin, the next generation of Banco Santander leadership -- including Botin's daughter, Ana Patricia -- faces the challenge of adapting the bank's model to a rapidly changing economy and customer base.

item.title: Home Health Care in India: In Search of the Right Business Model
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: Once a fragmented sector in India, home health care is catching the attention of entrepreneurs and investors and becoming an organized, technology-led industry in the country.

item.title: Can a Robot Be Your Boss?
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: Artificial intelligence and people analytics are allowing more and more of management tasks to become automated — but can they adapt to the all-too-human needs of employees?

item.title: What the BoA Settlement Means for the Bank – and for Banking
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: Despite the Justice Department’s ruling in the Bank of America mortgage case, it’s unlikely those hurt most will get any money, or that the outcome will prevent a re-occurrence.

item.title: The ‘Missed Opportunity’ in Israeli-Turkish Trade Relations
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: Israel’s trade with Turkey is growing, but strained diplomatic relations are hampering what could become a very strong partnership, experts say.

item.title: How Control Impacts What Consumers Expect from Brands
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: Consumers aren’t always looking for a “miracle product” to fix their problems — sometimes, they want to work hand-in-hand with a brand to succeed, Wharton research shows.

item.title: A Bias for Bonuses: What It Means for Your Paycheck
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: Firms are increasingly handing out performance-based bonuses instead of pay raises — and it’s an indicator that employers, not employees, hold all the cards in the job market.

item.title: Where the Financial Services Industry Goes from Here
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: The book 'A New Era in Banking: The Landscape After the Battle' examines the opportunities and challenges that lie ahead for the banking industry.

item.title: From Vaccines to Cheese Caves: Energizing the ‘Cold Chain’
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: The increasing need to deliver vaccines at the proper temperature to remote parts of the world is only one factor fueling the growth of the “cold chain” industry.

item.title: Autohome CEO Qin Zhi: From Pageviews to Deals
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: Qin Zhi, CEO of Chinese automobile website Autohome, says offering a one-stop solution to auto customers has been the firm's biggest advantage.

item.title: Beyond Ebola: What’s Needed to Combat the Next Outbreak
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: A sustainable, long-term health care infrastructure is required to deal with outbreaks like the deadly Ebola virus in West Africa, says Wharton's Ezekiel J. Emanuel.

item.title: The Race to Build a Better Smartphone Charger
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: Battery technology is waking up to the increasing demands of smartphone and tablet users — but can the innovation pipeline keep pace?

item.title: Why Businesses Should Serve Consumers’ ‘Higher Needs’
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: American psychologist Abraham Maslow is best known for his seminal research on the hierarchy of innate human needs, but his work also has a surprising application for businesses models and shareholder value.

item.title: Using Pop Culture to Defeat Gender Inequality
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: Mallika Dutt, founder of human rights group Breakthrough, discusses how she’s using the arts and multimedia to transform the social and cultural norms that promote violence against women.

item.title: How Physician Report Cards Can Improve Health Care
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: Research by Wharton health care management professor Jonathan Kolstad finds that showing physicians how they rate against peers is a powerful motivator for improving their game.

item.title: Can Creativity Be Taught?
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: Can creativity be fostered in the workplace, and if so, how can it be managed?

item.title: Telecom Companies Tap Analytics for Growth
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: Telecom providers worldwide face an enormous challenge: Even as traffic is increasing, revenues and profits are not keeping pace. Analytics can help.

item.title: The Role of Contagion in the Housing Boom (and Bust)
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: The housing boom of the mid 2000s spread from one neighboring locale to another in the U.S. Local fundamentals have only a limited ability to account for contagion, suggesting that non-rational forces also played a role, recent Wharton research finds.

item.title: The Lovers, the Haters and How They Helped Drive Innovation at Kraft
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: Kraft Foods’ vice president Barry Calpino discusses how the company reinvigorated aging brands and introduced some category-busting new ones -- and why the firm can’t afford to rest on its laurels.

item.title: Health Care Outcomes: When the More Effective Choice Costs More
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: Better models of care will go a long way toward spurring health care providers to make better choices between increased costs and improved outcomes, Wharton's Mark Pauly writes.

item.title: Why the ALS Ice Bucket Challenge Went Viral
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: The ALS Ice Bucket Challenge has raised millions of dollars toward fighting the disease and spawned millions of videos and shares on social media. Wharton's Jonah Berger discusses why the campaign went viral.

item.title: Improving Government Performance, Anticipating Citizens’ Needs
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: Predictive analytics is becoming a vital tool for governments trying to identify tax evaders or terrorists, to look for the best way to tackle a flu epidemic -- and more.

item.title: The Financial Hurdles to Rebuilding Puerto Rico’s Economy
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: Puerto Rico faces perhaps the most significant financial hurdles of anywhere in the United States. Can the island turn its economy around?

item.title: How Where You Live Impacts the Way You Use the Internet
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: In Location Is (Still) Everything: The Surprising Influence of the Real World on How We Search, Shop, and Sell in the Virtual One, Wharton’s David Bell provides deeper insight into e-commerce.

item.title: Where Are All the Women? The Changing Face of Technology
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: The book, Innovating Women: The Changing Face of Technology, attempts to address the barriers women face in the tech field by sharing their personal and professional stories.

item.title: NIIT Technologies’ Sudhir Chaturvedi: Companies Have to Decide What They Need from Big Data
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: Big data and predictive analytics have become fashionable today. But the fact that big data is so big means you must be clear about what you want.

item.title: Travel Industry Taps Technology to Win Over Customers
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: Technology is opening new ways for companies in the travel and hospitality industries to engage with customers and raise revenues.

item.title: Why You May Not Be as Ready for Retirement as You Think
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: A new book by Wharton's Richard Marston dispels some common beliefs about what Americans need to save for retirement.

item.title: Can India’s Modi Government Navigate the Tough Terrain of Labor Law Reform?
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi has promised to revamp India's labor laws, as he has done while chief minister in Gujarat. But the process won't be easy, experts say.

item.title: When Will the Economy Finally Bounce Back?
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: A recent survey from the Federal Reserve shows that a third of American households believe they are financially worse off than they were five years ago. Mark Zandi, chief economist at Moody’s Analytics, spoke with Knowledge@Wharton about what’s hampering economic recovery.

item.title: Why the New Labor Law Reforms Make India Fertile for Jobs
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: Recent changes to labor laws represent an important breakthrough in public policy for India, according to Teamlease founder Manish Sabharwal.

item.title: An Innovative Way to Improve Care for Chronically Ill Patients
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: Adopting a new model to treat such illnesses as diabetes and hypertension can cut down on hospital ER visits, according to new research by Wharton professor Guy David and four others.

item.title: Can the U.S. Afford Another War in Iraq?
item.dc:creator: Knowledge@Wharton
item.description: U.S. military involvement in Iraq raises big questions about the costs and impact on the nation's economy, say Wharton finance professor Bulent Gultekin and Boston University professor of political science Neta Crawford.
